column1: Mumps is a contagious disease that leads to painful swelling of the salivary glands.
The salivary glands produce saliva, a liquid that moistens food and helps you chew and swallow.
The mumps are caused by a virus.
The virus is spread from person to person by drops of moisture from your respiratory tract, such as when you sneeze.
Mumps most often occurs in children ages 2 - 12 who have not been vaccinated against the disease.

- Face pain - Fever - Headache - Sore throat - Swelling of the parotid glands (the largest salivary glands, located between the ear and the jaw) - Swelling of the temples or jaw (temporomandibular area) Other symptoms of this disease that can occur in males: - Testicle lump - Testicle pain - Scrotal swelling
